source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_040_chunk1
evidence_span: A cold-worked, stressrelieved (CwSR) commercial cladding was produced using similar thermo-mechanical processing encompassing tin contents ranging from 1.22 to 1.54%
test_type: thermal creep testing, tension testing, contractile strain ratio (CSR) testing, texture analysis

extra_properties.predominant_slip_system: basal slip at high tin contents to mixed basal-prism slip at low tin contents

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_040_chunk1
evidence_span: The steady state strain rates increased by factors of 6.5, and 2 for the 0:1, 1:1, and 2:1 stress states. respectively, as the tin content decreased toward the lower tin content limit of 1.20%

extra_properties.tin_content_effect: strongly dependent on tin content over allowable composition range

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_040_chunk2
evidence_span: The materials used in this program consisted of commercially produced Zircaloy-4 fuel rod cladding from three fuel designs. The cladding lots were designated A through H.
process_step: final tube reduction with high reduction in area, high Q factor, vacuum stress-relief anneal

extra_properties.anisotropy_coefficient_R_formula: R = (∂ε_θ/∂ε_r) for uniaxial test in axial direction
extra_properties.anisotropy_coefficient_P_formula: P = (∂ε_z/∂ε_r) for uniaxial test in hoop direction
extra_properties.grain_structure: unrecrystallized microstructure with highly anisotropic grain shape

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_040_chunk3
evidence_span: The contractile strain ratios (CSR) were measured during an interrupted uniaxial tension test at room temperature.
elastoplastic_model_formula: R = { \frac { ( \Delta \epsilon ) } { ( \Delta \epsilon _ { r } ) _ { \epsilon _ { z } = 2 . 5 ^ { c _ { c } } } } } \quad { \mathrm { u n i a x i a l ~ t e s t } } and \Delta \epsilon _ { r } = - \left( \Delta \epsilon _ { \theta } + \Delta \epsilon _ { z } \right)

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_040_chunk7
evidence_span: TABLE8—Empirical relationships that serve as a guide to the tin content on multiaxial thermal creep strains

anisotropy_parameters.P: changes toward isotropic conditions with decreasing tin content

extra_properties.slip_systems: prism slip dominates in low tin alloys, basal slip in high tin alloys
extra_properties.creep_rate_variation: factor of 6 increase (0:1), factor of 5 (1:1), factor of 2 (2:1) when tin decreases from 1.7% to 1.2%

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_040_chunk8
evidence_span: Irradiation of Zircaloy affects its microstructure and macroscopical properties, for example, influencing its irradiation growth

extra_properties.grain_size_effect: growth depends on grain size especially below 2 μm
extra_properties.dislocation_formation: irradiation-induced formation of dislocations with c-component occurs at neutron fluences ≥9×10²¹ cm⁻²
extra_properties.precipitate_dissolution: (Fe+Zr)-type intermetallic dissolves at fluences above 5×10²¹ cm⁻² at ≤300°C
extra_properties.precipitate_amorphization: (Fe+Cr+Zr)-type precipitates become amorphous and release iron to matrix
extra_properties.precipitate_ripening: size of intermetallics increases due to irradiation enhanced ripening at temperatures above 340°C
